syllabus:
Hand out of the syllabus and explanation of the course

This introductory lesson situates the objectives of the course. Readings that will be dealt with in class are to illustrate the contemporary socio-linguistic situation in Taiwan with a focus on language planning, standardization and ideology during the Japanese colonial period (1895-1945). The socio-political and literary background will be given attention, as well as some of the more recent (comparative) topics that regard language and society in Taiwan.

Students can work in group or independently, materials will be selected in the English language, but for those interested Chinese (Japanese) materials can be provided as elective readings. Language of instruction is English. 

**週****2  9****月** **19****日**    **Language in Taiwan: What do we observe?**

In the first half of this class, students will be asked to write down what they know about language in Taiwan, how they feel about it, what they observe, how come they think it is like that. What are representative languages for Taiwan today? Distribution of a number of language related sayings. Collecting answers and discussion.

The second half will relate the discussion to the sociolinguistic situation in colonial Taiwan, as to make the link with the course focus.     

**週****3  9** **月** **26****日**  **Language in Taiwan up to 1895**

Compulsory Reading:  Ann Heylen (2012), _Japanese Models_ Chapter I, “Historio-linguistic setting”,

Discussion of the chapter, elaborated and illustrated with a number of relevant secondary readings and source materials.

**週** **4  10****月****3****日**  **Background to the Japanese colonial period**

Compulsory Reading:  Ann Heylen (2012), _Japanese Models_ Chapter II

Discussion of the chapter, elaborated and illustrated with a number of relevant secondary readings that address different research topics in studying the Japanese colonial period in Taiwan history. Chapters and articles from the following authors will be distributed: Chou Wan-yao, Murray Rubinstein, Peter Duus and Raymon Myers, Liao Ping-hui and David Der-wei Wang 

**週****5  10****月****10****日**   **No class Double Ten Day**

**週****6  10****月** **17****日** **Models of Language Standardization and Planning (1)**

This class will introduce some of the theoretical concepts in 20th century language modernization, standardization and planning. Focus on East Asia (China and Japan, _yanwenyizhi_ /_genbunitchi_ movement) but also comparative with examples of language modernization in Europe.  

Preparatory reading: Heylen, Ann “ Loading the matrix”  

**週****7  10****月** **24****日** **Models of Language Standardization and Planning (2)**

This class will introduce some of the theoretical concepts in 20th century language modernization, standardization and planning. Focus on East Asia (China and Japan, _yanwenyizhi_ /_genbunitchi_ movement) but also comparative with examples of language modernization in Europe.   

**週****8   10****月** **31****日** **Lecture on Language in Colonial Taiwan (TBC)**

**週** **9   11****月** **7****日**  **Mid-term Exam**

**週****10  11****月** **14****日**  **Language Reform Movement:  Romanization**

Compulsory Reading:  Ann Heylen (2012), _Japanese Models_ Chapter III

Discussion of the chapter, elaborated and illustrated with a number of relevant secondary readings that contextualize the role of the Christian church in Taiwan society, and comparative with East Asia (China, Korea, Japan)

**週****11 11****月****21** **日**  **Language Reform Movement:  Mandarin baihuawawen**

Compulsory Reading:  Ann Heylen (2012), _Japanese Models_ Chapter IV

Discussion of the chapter, elaborated and illustrated with a number of relevant secondary readings that contextualize _Taiwan Minpao_, Japanese education and the aims of the assimilation policy vis–a-vis the tradition of Chinese classical education (_hanwen_).     

**週****12  11** **月** **28****日****Language Reform Movement: Written Taiwanese**

Compulsory Reading:  Ann Heylen (2012), _Japanese Models_ Chapter V

Discussion of the chapter, elaborated and illustrated with a number of relevant secondary readings that bring the other languages into the discussion orbit: Hakka, the indigenous languages and Esperanto.

**週****13  12****月** **5****日**  **Authors in English on Taiwan Language Topics: colonial period**

This class will provide a selection of English language works that discuss the language reform movements from a different perspective: literature and sociology  

**週****14  12****月** **12****日**  **Authors in English on Taiwan Language Topics: overview articles**

This class will focus on a number of general overview articles that deal with Taiwanese language planning and the transition from the colonial period into the postcolonial/war period. Ideological concepts will be discussed.   

**週****15  12****月** **19****日** **Language in Colonial Taiwan: legacy today** 

This class will look at current day language in Taiwan society and draw parallels with the Japanese colonial period. Topics of discussion will be advertising, literature, media and the attention to Japanese, English and languages of Southeast Asia.  

**週****16  12****月** **26****日** Tools and databases

Presentation of databases that store linguistic and language-related materials Taiwan.

**週****17  1****月** **2** **日** **General Discussion**

Instructions for the end-term exam paper

**週18  1月 9 日 End-term Exam**
